title: Hans-Martin Heyn
text:
I’m a senior lecturer at the Computer Science and Engineering Department of the University of Gothenburg and Chalmers University of Technology in Sweden. My research concentrates around Software Engineering for AI and distributed cyber-physical systems. I’m especially interested in studying how we can set reasonable data requirements for training and run-time data and implement fault detection for AI based on runtime data. A research direction that triggered my interest for achieving these aims is causal modelling. I’m teaching the courses EDA344 / LEU062 / DIT423: Data Communication, DAT257 / DIT257: Agile Software Project Management, and DAT550 / DIT978: Advanced Software Engineering for AI/ML-Enabled Systems.
On this site I keep a list of my publications, my CV, a list of my services and a list of theses I supervise. Feel free to contact me if you have questions.
In the autumn semester 2023, I have office hours as follows: Wednesday, 13:00 - 15:00



Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway
Ph.D. in Marine Cybernetics | September 2014 - October 2018 | Thesis: Motion Sensing on Vessels Operating in Sea Ice.
RWTH Aachen University, Aachen, Germany
M.Sc. Management, Business and Economics | October 2013 - March 2016 | Thesis: Route planning algorithm for electric logistic fleets in consideration of battery degradation.
M.Sc., Electrical Engineering, Information Technology and Computer Engineering | October 2010 - September 2013 | Thesis: Adaptive State- and Parameter Estimation for Lithium-Ion Batteries.
B.Sc., Electrical Engineering, Information Technology and Computer Engineering | October 2007 - September 2010 | Thesis: Safety concepts for high voltage battery storage systems.





An investigation of challenges encountered when specifying training data and runtime monitors for safety critical ML applications. Heyn, Hans-Martin, Knauss, Eric, Malleswarna, Iswarya and Dinakarna, Shruthi. 2023. Requirements Engineering: Foundation for Software Quality: 29th International Working Conference, REFSQ 2023. https://arxiv.org/pdf/2301.13476.pdf
A Compositional Approach to Creating Architecture Frameworks with an Application to Distributed AI Systems. Heyn, Hans-Martin, Knauss, Eric, and Pelliccione, Patrizio. 2023. Journal of Software and Systems (JSS). https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jss.2022.111604
Structural causal models as boundary objects in AI system development. Heyn, Hans-Martin and Knauss, Eric. 2022. Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on AI Engineering (CAIN). https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/3522664.3528615.

title: Hans-Martin Heyn
text:
THP-2023-2: Investigate the context dependency of fairness metrics for AI systems.
THP-2023-3: Explore causal models as specification language for ML models in cyberphysical systems.
THP-2023-4: Identify relevant safety standards for ML-enabled automotive perception systems and map their impact to elements of typical ML development pipelines for automotive systems.
The above topics can be defined as Master or Bachelor theses. I’m also open to topic suggestions by students that relate to my research interests. Please contact me for any suggestions and we can develop it into a thesis topic.



THP-2023-1: Explore how data needs / requirements are communicated between (ML) model-developers and experimenters in environmental research and investigate ways to improve this communication.
THP-2023-5: Explore causal models as a way to improve scientific grounding for studies on designing defect / fault detection.
THP-2023-6: Explore automated root cause analysis as part of an early problem identification process based on diagnostic trouble codes: a data-driven approach in the automotive industry
THP-2023-7: Investigate how to structure requirements for automotive perception systems and inter-relate between them especially in relation to safety aspects and fairness.
THP-2023-8: Investigate the reporting of data quality aspects in data portals and databases used for obtaining training data for ML models in environental research.



TH-4: Non-functional requirements and their impact on AGV based systems.,V Svensson, M Roudsari. 2023
TH-3: Challenges in Specifying Safety-Critical Systems with AI-Components. I Malleswaren, S Dinakaran. 2022
TH-2: Quality Attributes of Data in Distributed Deep Learning Architectures. SK Pradhan, S Tungal. 2021. Full text
TH-1: Deriving Contextual Definition and Requirements from Use Cases of Autonomous Drive. J Linder, P Subbiah. 2021. Full text

text:

Bachelor theses can at any time be defined. Please contact me if you are interested in a bachelor thesis.

AIRE’22, Ninth International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Requirements Engineering, Organisation Committee
RE’21, 29th IEEE International Requirements Engineering Conference, Virtualisation Co-Chair

title: Hans-Martin Heyn
text:
2023: Springer Machine Learning
2022: Elsevier Cold Regions Science and Technology
2021: Elsevier Cold Regions Science and Technology, Elsevier Journal of Systems & Software, IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering
2020: Elsevier Ocean Engineering

title: Hans-Martin Heyn
text:
THP-2023-2: Investigate the context dependency of fairness metrics for AI systems.
THP-2023-3: Explore causal models as specification language for ML models in cyberphysical systems.
THP-2023-4: Identify relevant safety standards for ML-enabled automotive perception systems and map their impact to elements of typical ML development pipelines for automotive systems.
The above topics can be defined as Master or Bachelor theses. I’m also open to topic suggestions by students that relate to my research interests. Please contact me for any suggestions and we can develop it into a thesis topic.



THP-2023-1: Explore how data needs / requirements are communicated between (ML) model-developers and experimenters in environmental research and investigate ways to improve this communication.
THP-2023-5: Explore causal models as a way to improve scientific grounding for studies on designing defect / fault detection.
THP-2023-6: Explore automated root cause analysis as part of an early problem identification process based on diagnostic trouble codes: a data-driven approach in the automotive industry
THP-2023-7: Investigate how to structure requirements for automotive perception systems and inter-relate between them especially in relation to safety aspects and fairness.
THP-2023-8: Investigate the reporting of data quality aspects in data portals and databases used for obtaining training data for ML models in environental research.



TH-4: Non-functional requirements and their impact on AGV based systems.,V Svensson, M Roudsari. 2023
TH-3: Challenges in Specifying Safety-Critical Systems with AI-Components. I Malleswaren, S Dinakaran. 2022
TH-2: Quality Attributes of Data in Distributed Deep Learning Architectures. SK Pradhan, S Tungal. 2021. Full text
TH-1: Deriving Contextual Definition and Requirements from Use Cases of Autonomous Drive. J Linder, P Subbiah. 2021. Full text
